newsitem.title: INDIA: India releases fresh sugar quota to curb prices.
newsitem.headline: India releases fresh sugar quota to curb prices.

text.p: The Indian government on Thursday released an additional 50,000 tonnes of sugar for free sale in May to check rising prices.
The government had earlier released a free sale quota of 750,000 tonnes of sugar for the month.
A Food Ministry statement said the price of free sale sugar had risen in the open market since the release of the quota.
"In order to contain this price rise, the government has decided to release an additional free sale quota of 50,000 tonnes for the month of May 1997," the statement said.
It said further releases, if necessary, would be made to keep the prices stable and curb speculation.
Sugar prices rose in India on Wednesday as speculators were encouraged by a shortage of ready stocks.

In the Bombay market in ready delivery, sugar S-30 climbed up by 10/15 rupees at 1,390/1,440 rupees per quintal (or 100 kgs) while sugar M-30 settled five rupees higher at 1,440/1,505 rupees per quintal.
